title: 107_hr2480
content:
The "Conservation Investment Act of 2001" increases the maximum number of acres allowed in the Conservation Reserve Program to 40,000,000 by 2011. It also establishes the Grassland Reserve Program under the Food Security Act of 1985. The Secretary will establish a grassland reserve program to assist owners in restoring and conserving eligible land. The program will enroll a maximum of 3,000,000 acres, with specific acreage requirements for restored and virgin grassland. Eligible land includes natural grass or shrubland in designated areas. Land eligible for the grassland reserve program includes areas historically dominated by natural grass or shrubland with potential for significant ecological value if restored, as well as incidental land necessary for efficient administration of the easement. "Land eligible for the grassland reserve program includes areas historically dominated by natural grass or shrubland with potential for significant ecological value if restored, as well as incidental land necessary for efficient administration of the easement." - SEC. 1238A. EASEMENTS AND AGREEMENTS. To enroll land in the grassland reserve program, the landowner must grant an easement to the Secretary, create a deed restriction, provide consent from interested parties, show proof of ownership, comply with easement terms, retire cropland base, and allow easement suspension in times of war, drought, or famine. The easement granted for the grassland reserve program allows for common grazing practices, haying, mowing, and construction of fire breaks and fences, while prohibiting certain activities during nesting seasons for declining bird species. The easement for the grassland reserve program allows common grazing practices, haying, mowing, and construction of fire breaks and fences. Prohibited activities include production of certain crops and disturbing the land surface. The Secretary will establish criteria for evaluating and ranking easement applications, with an emphasis on supporting native grasslands, grazing operations, and biodiversity. The Secretary will prescribe terms for restoring grassland under easements, with duties for landowners and the Federal government. Violations of easement or restoration agreements may result in penalties, including refunding payments with interest. Periodic inspections will be conducted to ensure compliance with easement terms. The Secretary will conduct periodic inspections to ensure compliance with easement terms, providing the landowner with adequate notice and allowing them or their representative to be present during inspections. "SEC. 1238B. Duties of Secretary include conducting periodic inspections for easement compliance." The Secretary provides easement payments, Federal share of restoration, and technical assistance to owners in exchange for granting an easement. Easement payments are based on the grazing value of the land, restoration costs are partially covered, and technical assistance is offered for easement execution and grassland restoration. The Commodity Credit Corporation reimburses the Secretary for a portion of easement acquisition costs and restoration payments. If an entitled owner is unable to receive payment, the Secretary will make the payment in a fair manner. Easement payments do not affect other federal payments the owner may receive. "SEC. 1238C. ADMINISTRATION." The Secretary may allow private organizations or State agencies to hold and enforce easements for grassland conservation if certain conditions are met. Organizations must apply for approval and demonstrate competence in administering grassland easements. If an organization holding an easement terminates, reassignment may be necessary. The owner of land under this subchapter must reassign easements to another approved organization or the Secretary upon termination. Regulations for this process must be issued within 180 days. Funding amendments are made to include subchapters C and D. SEC. 4. INCREASE IN MAXIMUM NUMBER OF ACRES AUTHORIZED TO BE ENROLLED IN THE WETLANDS RESERVE PROGRAM. The total number of acres enrolled in the wetlands reserve program is increased annually from 1,225,000 acres in fiscal year 2002 to 2,575,000 acres in fiscal year 2011. SEC. 5. ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY INCENTIVES PROGRAM. SEC. 5. ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY INCENTIVES PROGRAM. Funding for the program is increased to $1.4 billion for fiscal year 2002 and $1.2 billion for each fiscal year from 2003 to 2011. Contract terms are amended to allow for 1 to 10-year contracts. Payment limitations are repealed. SEC. 7. FUNDING OF FARMLAND PROTECTION PROGRAM.

    Section 388(c) of the Federal Agriculture Improvement and Reform Act of 1996 is amended to allocate $50,000,000 annually from 2002 to 2011 for the program.

SEC. 8. SMALL WATERSHED REHABILITATION AMENDMENTS OF 2000.

    Section 14(h) of the Watershed Protection and Flood Prevention Act is amended to provide $60,000,000 each year from 2002 to 2011.

SEC. 9. EFFECTIVE DATE.

    The amendments made by this Act will be effective on October 1, 2001.
